title: Add a future directions / vision for UNF slide
description: For a job talk, the search committee wants to know what you would bring to UNF specifically. The deck currently ends with Bibliography -> Questions. Consider adding a slide before the closing that outlines: future research directions, how your work connects to UNF's programs and facilities (MIDI Lab mentioned in the brief), potential student project opportunities, courses you could teach or develop. This signals forward momentum and fit with the institution.
close_reason: Added Future Directions slide with place-based sound art methodology, Above and Below as example, and student mentorship framing. Generalized to be location-independent.

title: Highlight student collaboration more prominently
description: The UNF brief explicitly mentions 'projects they have completed with students.' Currently Carter Gordon's role in Resonant Landscapes is mentioned in one speaker note and one photo caption. The Resonant Landscapes concert slides show student performers but don't name them or describe the pedagogical context. Add explicit framing about mentoring students in research — Carter as undergraduate collaborator on Resonant Landscapes (co-author on Audio Mostly paper), the DSU concert as a student-driven creative outcome, and any MatchLab internship students.

title: Replace Research Overview table with a more engaging visual
description: The Research Overview slide (slide 3) is a plain markdown table listing works and years. For a presentation, a visual timeline or thematic diagram would be more engaging and help the audience see the narrative arc: from performer-controlled notation (And the water receded) -> audience participation (A more perfect union, Mesh Garden) -> locative/outdoor (Sounds Aware, Resonant Landscapes) -> current research (MatchLab, Drift). Consider a horizontal timeline with thematic labels, or at minimum add a brief thematic subtitle to each entry in the table.
close_reason: Tried a visual alternative, didn't work. Plain table is fine as a quick roadmap slide.

title: Consider pacing for 1-hour format
description: The brief says the session is 1 hour total. The current deck has ~40 slides including video embeds. With Q&A time, that's roughly 35-45 minutes of presentation. The YouTube embed for 'And the water receded' starts at 5:30 — how long will you play it? The Vimeo embeds for 'A more perfect union' and 'immaterial.cloud' also need planned durations. Consider adding time cues in speaker notes (e.g., 'play 1 minute of video') and think about whether the pacing allows enough time for Drift and MatchLab — the current/future work that will excite the committee most.

title: Add a technology expertise / technical range slide
description: The brief asks candidates to demonstrate 'expertise in the field' of music technology. The deck shows individual works but never explicitly frames the breadth of technical skills: Web Audio API, peer-to-peer networking (WebRTC), ambisonics and spatial audio, GPS/gyroscope sensor integration, Arduino/microcontrollers, genetic algorithms, granular synthesis, ML/semantic audio retrieval. A single slide near the beginning (after the smartphone platform slide) or woven into the Research Overview could make the technical depth visible at a glance. This is especially important for a committee that may not be deeply familiar with every technology mentioned.
close_reason: Not needed — individual project slides already demonstrate technical range in context. A standalone tech skills slide would feel like resume padding.

title: Add student pieces from Resonant Landscapes concert to address 'work with students' brief requirement
description: Add content about student pieces from the Resonant Landscapes concert to the slide deck. The interview brief asks about 'work you did with students' — this concert is a strong example of student collaboration and creative work. Include relevant student compositions/performances and context about the concert.

title: Strengthen speaker notes for concert and image-only slides
description: Several slides have minimal or repetitive speaker notes: the Resonant Landscapes concert slides (slides 33-36) all say the same thing ('DSU faculty and students composed works...'). The image-only slides for League of Automatic Music Composers and Karl Sims have notes but could better connect back to your own work. The Sounds Aware UI screenshots (slides 19-20) have thin notes. These are opportunities to add talking points that connect each slide to the broader narrative — especially important for a 1-hour presentation where you'll need substantial speaking material.

title: Add visuals or demo for MatchLab
description: MatchLab is currently just bullet points on two slides — no screenshots, no UI mockup, no demo. For a music technology job talk, showing the semantic sound search tool in action would be much more compelling than describing it. Add at least a screenshot or mockup of the plugin UI, or a short diagram showing the search workflow (text/audio query -> embedding -> results). If a live demo is planned, note that in the speaker notes.
close_reason: Project is in early research stages — no UI to show yet. Current slides accurately reflect the state of the work.
